title: Practice Challenge
description:
Create variables:
1. A 'const' variable called 'city' that stores the text 'New York'.
2. A 'let' variable called 'temperature' that stores the number 72.
3. Use console.log to display both variables.
instructions:
Create variables:
1. A 'const' variable called 'city' that stores the text 'New York'.
2. A 'let' variable called 'temperature' that stores the number 72.
3. Use console.log to display both variables.

hints.text: Remember: const city = 'some city'; and let temperature = 72; Then use console.log for each.

commonMistakes.consequence: Writing just age = 25; instead of let age = 25; causes an error in strict mode or creates a global variable.
commonMistakes.correction: Always declare variables with let or const: let age = 25;

commonMistakes.mistake: Using 'let' or 'const' when updating a variable
commonMistakes.consequence: Writing let age = 25; let age = 26; throws an error because you can't redeclare the same variable.
commonMistakes.correction: Only use let/const when creating. To update: let age = 25; age = 26;

commonMistakes.mistake: Using const for values that need to change
commonMistakes.consequence: Trying to reassign a const variable throws a TypeError.
commonMistakes.correction: Use let for values that will change, const for values that stay the same.
